author: @OhMyOhMi
text: Just started course 6, my thought Google certificate is that they really starts from scratch assuming you have absolutely zero experience. They emphasize on the basics and concept but does not go in depth into further slightly advance tutorials. So don't expect to be spoon fed, after knowing the basic concept, I highly recommend to take additional intermediate level courses to improve yourself. Relying solely on this certificate teachings definitely will not prep you up to expectation. You're not going to be an expert after this course. It's a really good start for beginners like me though.

author: @shivasuresh5957
text: Hi Alex, thanks so much for introducing the Google Data Analytics Certificate program to us. I completed all 7 courses plus the capstone project to obtain the certification. I started around March 18th so it feels good to successfully finish it. I spent many hours the last 6-7 weeks going through the courses so it does involve a certain amount of commitment but it is worth it since I learned quite a bit about best practices in data analysis. I was a bit skeptical about R since I have been using Python but now I have a very basic understanding of R as well. R wasn't too hard to pick up since it also uses packages and data frames similar to Python. There are some differences in syntax as to be expected. Thanks again for bringing the program to my attention.

author: @vincentyu2596
text: When you look at the side by side comparison lining up the tech stack against each other, BigQuery vs DB2, Tableau vs COGNOS the Google Cert has better real world application. Outside of the R vs Python argument there's a stronger knowledge base in the Google Cert overall. Plus let's be honest, what you're really paying for is the post certification support. Resume prep, interview practice, help with portfolio work, this is the bread and butter. With the IBM cert, you complete it and that's it.

author: @Cherub1387
text: Can you do a video on your thoughts about how this will affect the market? I'm not a data analyst yet, but the certification actually makes me nervous. I've heard nothing but how valuable data analysts are and how much quality analysts are needed. With the cert, it almost seems like Google is trying to flood the market, so to speak. And we all know that when there's an over-abundance of something, the value of it decreases. Plus, there's also so much talk about how many aspects of data analysis might become automated in the near future. Idk. I guess I'm just nervous about investing so much time and effort into something that might just end up the tech equivalent of working at McDonald's. I hope that makes sense.
